awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2019 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Jasper Weinburd, "Dynamics of Band Morphology in Foraging Locusts: A Two-Model Approach." The host institution for the fellowship is Harvey Mudd College, and the sponsoring scientist is Andrew Bernoff.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Locusts are serious agricultural pests that exhibit social behavior and collective movement. In a precursor to devastating flying swarms, flightless nymphs form hopper bands that march along the ground in a common direction, often through agricultural regions, causing significant damage to crops that can result in food insecurity for local communities. Hopper bands take on a variety of morphologies that range from streaming columns to planar fronts, see primary image attached. Hopper band morphology appears to serve ecological functions for the collective group, namely foraging and migration, but the mechanisms that give rise to these collective behaviors are not well understood. This project has contributed to our understanding of how an individual’s behavioral response to social and environment cues (that is the microscopic description) leads to these morphologies (that is the macroscopic observables). Furthering this connection can inform development of more efficient and effective strategies for controlling and disrupting harmful swarms. Moreover, results from this project may contribute more broadly to understanding collective behavior in other ecological (livestock herds, fish schools) and human (crowd control, traffic) contexts.

The primary research outcomes from this project are contained in two publications [1, 2]. First, the principal investigator (PI) pursued a two-model investigation that links individual behaviors of an agent-based model (ABM) to collective mechanisms in a partial differential equation (PDE) for the density in the continuum limit. An ABM provides an immediate connection to observable biology, allowing incorporation of individual behaviors derived directly from data. A continuum PDE model allows global characterization of collective behavior via bifurcation analysis of steady states and stability theory. By investigating both in tandem one can infer individual mechanisms based on resulting collective behavior, as we have done in [1]. Our approach presents a significant opportunity for rigorous mathematical analysis closely linked to biological data.
The second publication [2] represents the beginning of a collaboration with world-class insect ecologists in Australia and the PI's development of a new set of skills in data science. Along with numerous undergraduate co-authors (denoted with * below), we digitized individual trajectories from video of locusts recorded in the field, see attached image. We used tools from statistical learning to extract trends in individual interaction. In particular, we show that moving locusts are less likely to have neighbors ahead of them than to their right or left, suggesting an individual-level mechanism for collision avoidance. The results provide novel insight into emergent behavior in locust swarms and will inform ongoing modeling work.
The human resources impact of this project, especially on the PIs scientific development, cannot be overstated. During the course of the award, the PI had secured a tenure-track faculty position at a university sharing their goals and values for the future of mathematics and higher education. They had presented at over a dozen conferences and colloquia, despite the disruptions of the COVID pandemic. Finally, the PI also mentored a dozen undergraduate students including six identifying as female and four identifying as non-white. Through their work the PI, ten of these were introduced to research in mathematics for the first time.

[1] Andrew J. Bernoff, Michael Culshaw-Maurer, Rebecca A. Everett, Maryann E. Hohn, W. Christopher Strickland, and Jasper Weinburd (2020). Agent-based and continuous models of hopper bands for the Australian plague locust: How resource consumption mediates pulse formation and geometry. PLOS Computational Biology 16(5): e1007820. DOI: 10.1371/journal.pcbi.1007820

[2] Jasper Weinburd, Jacob Landsberg*, Anna Kravtsova*, Shanni Lam*, Tarush Sharma*, Stephen J. Simpson, Gregory A. Sword, and Camille Buhl (2024). Anisotropic interaction and motion states of locusts in a hopper band. Proc. R. Soc. B. 291:20232121. DOI: 10.1098/rspb.2023.2121
